L1_summary_of_paper: Formal analytical model of a vertically differentiated duopoly showing how two social-interaction mechanisms reshape firms’ quality choices, pricing, profits, and welfare across two selling periods. Market-expansion effect (MEE) is a cross-brand, informative spillover: first-period sales enlarge the second-period potential market for everyone. Value-enhancement effect (VEE) is product-exclusive utility gain (network-like): a buyer’s utility rises with the same-brand’s current and/or prior sales (VEE-C, VEE-P). Stage 1: firms simultaneously choose qualities (upper bound normalized to 1). Stage 2: they set committed prices for two periods (dynamic pricing and cost structures analyzed as extensions). Core results: For given qualities, both MEE and VEE intensify price competition; however, in equilibrium MEE induces the low-quality firm to raise quality (shrinking differentiation), lowers both firms’ prices, increases both demands and profits, and raises consumer surplus and social welfare (win–win). VEE pushes the low-quality firm to lower quality (widening differentiation), raises the high-quality firm’s price and profit while reducing the low-quality firm’s profit (Matthew effect); consumer monetary surplus falls, although total welfare can rise once the added social utility is counted; patterns are qualitatively robust for both VEE-C and VEE-P and under dynamic pricing (effects largely unchanged). Combined-effects numerics show that relative magnitudes of MEE and VEE govern outcomes, with VEE-C generally stronger than VEE-P.
A1_citation: Geng, X., Guo, X., & Xiao, G. (2022). Impact of social interactions on duopoly competition with quality considerations. Management Science, 68(2), 941–959. https://doi.org/10.1287/mnsc.2021.3972
C2_measurement: Other: Analytical model parameters (no empirical measurement)
C3_metric_detail: Social-interaction intensities: r (MEE strength), tc (VEE-current), tp (VEE-previous); parameters constrained to ensure partial coverage and interior solutions.
D2_key_assumptions_addressed: Uniform θ ∼ U[0,1] (willingness to pay for quality) and single-unit demand
Two periods; committed prices in main model; dynamic pricing analyzed as extension
Zero costs in main model; convex setup and linear marginal costs considered in extension
Parameter bounds: 0 < r ≤ 1; tc, tp small to ensure partial market coverage and positive demands
Existence/uniqueness of pure-strategy subgame-perfect equilibrium under each case
D2_robustness_suite: Cost structures (fixed setup and marginal costs)
F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Findings rely on stylized assumptions (uniform preferences, two periods, partial coverage constraints, costless main model). External validity depends on how closely real markets match these mechanisms.
G1_construct_mapping_note: Maps MEE to cross-brand informational diffusion (market-size spillover) and VEE to same-brand utility externalities; links these to firms’ vertical differentiation and pricing choices and to welfare components.
G4_unifying_props_drafts: When social interactions primarily expand awareness (MEE), firms converge in quality and both profit despite tougher price competition.
When interactions primarily enhance same-brand value (VEE), firms diverge in quality and profits polarize (high-quality gains, low-quality loses).
Relative magnitudes of MEE and VEE determine whether markets experience mutual gain or Matthew effects; VEE-C generally dominates VEE-P due to immediacy.
NA_reason_if_any: Analytical/theoretical paper; no empirical measurement or data collection.
I1_mechanism_statements: MEE: first-period sales expand second-period market for both firms (informational spillover), inducing the low-quality firm to raise quality to capture more coverage despite fiercer price competition; the larger pie offsets margin erosion so both profits rise.

VEE: same-brand interactions raise buyers’ utility for that brand, magnifying the high-quality firm’s advantage; the low-quality firm retreats by lowering quality to avoid head-to-head competition, widening differentiation and polarizing profits.

Time-lag distinction: VEE-P requires first-period scale to harvest second-period utility gains, prompting aggressive first-period pricing by the high-quality firm; VEE-C’s utility gain is immediate and typically stronger.

I2_mediation_moderation_details.role_in_link: Amplifies the effect of first-period demand expansion on second-period market size and on both firms’ profits.
Strengthens the asymmetric advantage of high quality, widening quality and profit gaps; immediacy (tc) > lagged (tp).

I3_theoretical_propositions: In a vertically differentiated duopoly with MEE, equilibrium quality differentiation shrinks, prices fall, and both firms’ profits and consumer welfare rise.

In the same duopoly with VEE (current or previous), equilibrium quality differentiation widens; the high-quality firm’s price and profit increase while the low-quality firm’s profit declines; consumer monetary surplus falls.
The combined impact of MEE and VEE decomposes into their individual effects; relative magnitudes determine which mechanism dominates market outcomes, with VEE-C typically stronger than VEE-P.
J1_main_findings_summary: MEE lowers prices, induces the low-quality firm to raise quality, and increases both firms’ demands and profits; consumer surplus and social welfare rise.
VEE widens quality gaps: the high-quality firm raises price and profit; the low-quality firm lowers quality and loses profit (Matthew effect); consumer monetary surplus declines.

VEE-C and VEE-P yield qualitatively similar equilibrium outcomes; VEE-C generally has stronger effects than VEE-P due to immediacy; VEE-P prompts stronger first-period pricing to build installed base.
Dynamic pricing and positive costs do not overturn the qualitative results; differences versus committed pricing are modest.
J2_finding_evidence_links: Abstract and model overview (types of social interactions; main findings).
Benchmark and equilibrium structure (q̂_H=1, q̂_L=4/7 in baseline).
MEE: reduced differentiation; both firms’ profits and welfare rise (Corollary 1).
VEE-C and VEE-P: widened differentiation; H gains, L loses; consumer monetary surplus falls; welfare decomposition (Corollaries 2–3).
Combined effects and relative strength (VEE-C stronger than VEE-P; potential distortion under strong VEE).
Dynamic pricing extensions; modest quantitative differences.
K1_contribution_summary: Introduces a clear theoretical distinction between cross-brand informational spillovers (MEE) and same-brand utility externalities (VEE) in competitive quality–price settings, showing that MEE delivers mutual gains and convergence in quality whereas VEE generates polarization and a Matthew effect; establishes robustness across timing (current vs previous consumers), pricing regimes, and basic cost structures.
